passage_text: The Land Belongs to the Children Vande Mataram, Vande Mataram. Walk with a sway to the sound of the waves by the oceanside. Boy, see the girl, she answers you back with her bashful eyes. ...and the land, the land belongs to the children, they are the land and the song that they sing: Vande Mataram, Vande Mataram. its very simple. vande means praise, salute and Mataram means your mother, your country, your motherland. i dunno why people are making such a fuss about saluting your motherland.dont listen to who is saying what, just salute your motherland and apna kaam karo.

Vande Mataram (Sanskrit: Vande Mātaram I do homage to the mother;) is a poem in the 1882 novel Anandamatha by Bankimchandra Chattopadhyay. It is written in a mixture of Bengali and Sanskrit. It is a hymn to the goddess Durga, identified as the national personification of Bengal.

The core of Vande Mataram is a hymn to goddess Durga: this is so plain that there can be no debate about it. Of course Bankimchandra does show Durga to be inseparably united with Bengal in the end, but no Mussulman [Muslim] can be expected patriotically to worship the ten-handed deity as Swadesh [the nation].
